div1.head: English translation [from French] of letter from [s.n.] Seguin to the Medical Inspector, Director of the Health Service of French West Africa, October 31, 1922
div1.opener:
Seguin 1 & 3 2
Copy
FRENCH SUDAN.
HEALTH SERVICE.
Bamako,
October 31, 1922
No. 337
div1.p:
Séguin, chief physician, 2nd class, Head of the Health Service of the
French Sudan, to the Medical Inspector and Director of the Health Service of
French West Africa. Dakar.

I have the honor to confirm my telegram No. 121 of October 28, announcing
the death of the postal employee Mr. N., who had taken to his bed on the 23rd, the
morning of the day on which I left Ségou, with a high fever. This fever had come
on slowly with light back-ache, headache without facial congestion, a very slightly
coated tongue, little or no lumbar pain, nothing that resembled the classic “coup
de barre” in the small of the back.

Summing up, Mr. N. presented nothing but the symptoms of a very ordinary
feverish gastric disturbance, with nothing that would have made it possible to make
a diagnosis of yellow fever, no matter how much one might have been justly preju-
diced in favor of this latter hypothesis.

Mr. N. thought that he had got a light sunstroke from working in front of
a door in the full sunshine, which was not at all improbable. I made an examination
of his blood, and the results were negative as far as the hematozoa of malaria and
the spirochetes of recurrent fever were concerned.

In the evening, half an hour before my leaving Ségou, I went back to see
Mr. N., whose condition had remained absolutely unchanged. I left him in the care
of Dr. Fortin, advising him to repeat the blood examinations and to watch the patient
very carefully for signs of yellow fever.

On passing through Koulikoro on October 25, we were informed by the
Governor of the content of the following telegram, which was waiting for him there,
-2-
“Dr. Fortin announces state of postal employee N. is stationary; temperature morning
39.4, evening 39.6; complexion slightly more congested than at first; tongue very
much coated; no icterus; normal urine; no vomit.” The diagnosis of yellow fever was
becoming more probable.

On the 27th Dr. Fortin telegraphed, “Condition of postal employee N.
isolated in Maternity must be considered very serious. Slight black hemorrhagic
vomit appeared this morning, as well as stools of the same hemorrhagic type. Urine
albuminous, but normal in quantity. Prognosis very reserved.”

From then on the diagnosis of yellow fever could be made with complete cer-
tainty and the sanitary measures already arranged for in Ségou could be carried out.

In fact, the Governor immediately issued the decree which was transmitted
to Dakar by telegraph, which has certainly come to your knowledge by this time, and
to which some modification were made in accordance with instructions from Dakar.

I have already sent you my report No. 329, which will inform you as to the
beginning of the little epidemic of yellow fever in Ségou. I am firmly convinced
that it will quickly be extinguished on the spot.

The question now is to seek the origin of this little local epidemic, aris-
ing in the midst of the Sudan, and far from the limits of our jurisdiction beyond
which yellow fever might flourish. A case of yellow fever was undoubtedly reported
at Accra on the Gold Coast last July, but there is no connection between Ségou or
the Sudan with the Gold Coast, and this origin seems very unlikely.

I have been told that the natives of Ségou are in the habit of going into
the forests of the Ivory Coast of Liberia and the Gold Coast to gather kola nuts.
Could they have brought back more or less attenuated germs of yellow fever from
there? This is however no more than a supposition, as I am completely ignorant of
the health conditions of the native populations of those regions.

For my own part, I think it is much simpler to admit that yellow fever is
definitely a disease endemic in the Sudan, that the yellow fever germ develops in a
-3-
latent fashion in the negro, remaining moderately virulent for a longer or shorter
time, and becoming suddenly active at considerable intervals when the successive
transferences from one person to another bring it to new organisms, especially
whites, who have no natural or acquired immunity. It may therefore be true that the
mild cases of icterus that are sometimes found in negroes aside from all infection
with the Obermayer spirochete or the Laveran hematozoon are very mild manifestations
of yellow fever, and I believe that from now on such cases of icterus, that have no
evident source of origin, should be considered as very probably yellow fever, and be
isolated.

As far as Ségou is concerned, the measures required by the sanitary regu-
lations have already been taken, as I said before. Dr. Alexandre has been kept in
Ségou to assist Dr. Fortin, less to care for the patients than to assist in controlling
the measures that must be directed and inspected by a physician in order to produce
the required results.

At the last moment I have received a telegram from the Governor informing
me of the death of Mr. O. of the Niger Mission.

Mr. O. was isolated from the 20th on the day of our arrival in Ségou, in
a tent at Banankora, 10 kilometers down the river from Ségou. According to the tele-
grams, he was transported sick to the Maternity Hospital at Ségou on the 28th, and died
on the 31st. This case clearly proves that a period of observation of 6 days is
absolutely insufficient for discovering the disease. For I do not assume that Mr. O.
was infected at Banankora, but that he went there already in a state of incubation
on the 20th, having been infected by a mosquito in the house of the C.F.A.O., where
he lived with Mr. A. and Mr. B., who both died of yellow fever. This fact speaks de-
finitely enough in favor of a period of incubation longer than the one generally
accepted, and I propose that the period of observation be extended to 10 days, as had
first been agreed upon with the Governor of the Sudan. I think that in such a serious
matter, and considering the difficulty of watching the suspects from hour to hour,
-4-
a wider margin should be allowed for the period of observation, and that the regu-
lation that reduced it to 6 days was perhaps imprudent.

I am giving you my honest opinion, according to the facts of the case,
so that you can present them to the Governor-General, to whom the Governor of the
Sudan has already telegraphed the same suggestion, and so that you can make the
necessary decision.
